If you are majoring in a program within the College of Media and Entertainment, you should seek advisement regarding the courses you may take to satisfy requirements of the minor.

The Nutrition and Food Science minor at MTSU provides students with a foundational understanding of nutrition principles and food science concepts. This minor is an excellent complement to a variety of majors, including those in health sciences, exercise science, biology, chemistry, and hospitality. Students will learn about human nutrition, food preparation, food safety, and the role of food in health and disease. The curriculum emphasizes both the scientific aspects of food and nutrition and their practical applications. This minor is designed to enhance students' career readiness in fields related to health, wellness, food industry, and consumer education.

A minor in political science requires 15 credit hours of Political Science (POS) courses. The minor will provide students with a basic understanding of government and politics in the United States and around the world, as well as the major subfields of political science. It is an excellent complement to several majors at MTSU, including Criminal Justice Administration, Economics, History, Global Studies, and Social Work.

Our Professional Selling Certificate program is a non-credit executive education program offered to the general public, designed to help individuals acquire the skills and confidence necessary to excel in a dynamic sales environment. Whether you are new to sales, a seasoned professional looking to refine your techniques, or an entrepreneur aiming to boost your business, this certificate will equip you with practical strategies and insights for immediate impact. Our program blends theoretical knowledge with real-world applications, ensuring a comprehensive learning experience. In this program, participants will gain an understanding of: The fundamentals of the sales process, including prospecting, lead generation, and client relationship management. Effective communication and negotiation strategies tailored for sales interactions. How to identify customer needs and present solutions that resonate. Building long-term client relationships and fostering customer loyalty. Utilizing technology and data analytics to enhance sales performance. Ethical considerations and professional conduct in sales.

By adding a Psychology minor, students gain valuable knowledge about human behavior, cognition, and emotion that can complement any major. This minor enhances critical thinking, research skills, and an understanding of psychological principles, making graduates more versatile and appealing to a wide range of employers or for further academic pursuits.

Public Health is the science and art of preventing disease, prolonging life and promoting health through the organized efforts and informed choices of society, organizations, public and private communities and individuals. Public health addresses human health at the population level, and a minor in Public Health complements any major because every career field directly or indirectly impacts the health of its workers, clients, or communities.

The Public Relations minor requires 18 hours. These hours include three core classes plus three additional classes from a list of approved courses. The PR minor provides students with a solid foundation in the concepts and practices of public relations, preparing them for a variety of entry-level positions in the field. Students learn to research, plan, implement, and evaluate public relations campaigns, as well as develop strong written and oral communication skills.

The Medieval Studies minor introduces students to the culture, history, and literature of medieval Europe (c. 500-1500 C.E.). Students will gain familiarity with the period through a series of core courses and electives, developing a deeper understanding of the foundations of Western civilization. Medieval Studies combines the traditional disciplines of history and English with art, philosophy, religious studies, and foreign languages. Students pursuing the minor will encounter the history, thought, culture, and literature of this fascinating period and learn more about the Middle Ages in Europe and beyond.

The Department of Theatre and Dance offers a minor in Musical Theatre Performance. The Musical Theatre Minor provides students interested in musical theatre a focused course of study that combines acting, dance, and music. This minor is open to all students, regardless of major. It is especially suitable for Theatre majors with an emphasis in performance, Dance majors, and Music majors with an emphasis in voice or instrumental performance.

The Great Books Minor provides students with the opportunity to engage with the enduring questions raised in some of the most influential works of literature, philosophy, history, and science. Students will explore a wide range of texts, from ancient epics to modern novels, delving into fundamental themes such as justice, truth, beauty, and the human condition. The minor emphasizes critical thinking, close reading, and robust discussion, fostering a deeper understanding of intellectual traditions and their continued relevance. Through rigorous engagement with these foundational texts, students will enhance their analytical and communication skills, preparing them for diverse academic and professional pursuits.

The African American Studies minor offers an interdisciplinary approach to understanding the history, culture, and social experiences of people of African descent, particularly in the United States. This program encourages students to critically engage with diverse perspectives and research methodologies. Through coursework in various fields such as history, literature, sociology, political science, and music, students will explore the significant contributions of African Americans, examine issues of race and identity, and analyze dynamics of power, social justice, and resistance. The minor enhances critical thinking, research skills, and cultural competency, preparing students for diverse careers and engaged citizenship.

The Entrepreneurship Minor provides students with the critical skills and knowledge needed to launch, manage, and grow new ventures successfully. It focuses on developing an entrepreneurial mindset, understanding market opportunities, securing funding, and creating sustainable business models. This minor is suitable for students across all disciplines who aspire to become entrepreneurs, innovators, or leaders in established organizations.

This minor allows students to apply scientific and engineering principles to the research, design, development, construction, installation, maintenance, and operation of electrical and electronic systems and their components. This minor is typically pursued by students majoring in other technical areas (e.g., Computer Science, Engineering Technology, Mechatronics, Physics, etc.) but is available to all students. The minor provides a basic foundation in electronics applicable to a variety of careers. The minor requires 18 hours including: ET 1600; ET 2610; ET 2660; and 9 hours of approved ET electives from 3000/4000 level.

The Engineering Systems minor is intended to provide fundamental knowledge and skills needed to understand and manage complex systems. The minor will cover topics such as system design, analysis, optimization, and control, as well as the use of various tools and techniques to model, simulate, and evaluate system performance. Students who complete the Engineering Systems minor will be well-prepared to pursue careers in a variety of fields, including aerospace, automotive, manufacturing, and telecommunications.

Middle Tennessee State University is adding a new major: Africana Studies. Beginning in fall 2021, students will be able to pursue a Bachelor of Arts in Africana Studies, a comprehensive interdisciplinary program designed to examine the histories, cultures, and intellectual traditions of people of African descent across Africa and the diaspora. The degree examines the histories, cultures and intellectual traditions of people of African descent across Africa and the diaspora. Students will develop strong analytical and communication skills, as well as cultural competency necessary to thrive in an increasingly diverse and globalized world. The new major will teach students to think critically, communicate effectively, analyze issues, and provide historical and contemporary context for addressing questions of race, identity, culture and power within local, national and global communities. It prepares graduates for a variety of careers in social work, law, education, journalism, government, public policy and non-profit organizations. It will also serve as strong preparation for graduate studies.

Africana Studies is an interdisciplinary program that brings together the study of African American, African, and Caribbean peoples, cultures, and societies from a global perspective. The curriculum is designed to equip students with critical analytical and research skills applicable to diverse careers. Students in the Africana Studies major will have the opportunity to delve into various aspects of the Black experience, including history, literature, politics, economics, sociology, and culture. The program emphasizes interdisciplinary approaches, encouraging students to explore the complexities of race, identity, power, and social justice.

The African Studies minor is an interdisciplinary program designed to provide students with a broad understanding of the histories, cultures, societies, economies, and politics of Africa and its diaspora. Students will explore diverse perspectives on African experiences, challenge stereotypes, and develop critical thinking skills necessary for engaging with complex global issues. The minor aims to foster cross-cultural understanding, prepare students for careers in fields with international dimensions, and equip them with a global perspective invaluable in an interconnected world.

This minor prepares students for global citizenship and careers in government, education, law, business, and nonprofit organizations working in or with Asian countries. The minor focuses on the languages, cultures, histories, and political and economic systems of Asian societies. The curriculum requires 18 hours. These hours must include a minimum of 6 hours in Asian Studies (ASIA) courses, 3 hours in Asian language courses (Chinese, Japanese, or Arabic), and 9 hours of electives chosen from an approved list of courses. At least 9 hours must be at the 3000–4000 level. Students must maintain a minimum 2.0 GPA in all minor courses. The Asian Studies minor can be paired with any major.

This minor is designed for students who desire to enhance their understanding of the scientific method as it applies to the social, behavioral, and health sciences. The Behavioral Research minor would be appropriate for any student interested in: (a) graduate education in a social, behavioral, or health science; (b) careers in research (e.g., as a research assistant); or (c) applying research skills to problems in community organizations, business, or government. The minor is highly customizable to meet a student’s specific interests and needs.

The Classical Studies minor provides students with the opportunity to take courses in Latin and Greek language as well as ancient history, literature, philosophy, and mythology. The minor gives students the chance to explore the foundations of Western civilization and learn about topics like Roman generals, Greek heroes, and classical architecture. It is an excellent complement to many majors, including English, History, Philosophy, Political Science, and Foreign Languages. Students pursuing a minor in Classical Studies should complete 15 hours of coursework in subjects related to classical antiquity. Students should work with their advisors to select courses that best fit their interests and complement their major.
